title: 113_hr3501
content: The Act may be cited as the "Generational Residences and Nurturing Dwellings Act" or the "GRAND Act." It pertains to housing for elderly caregivers. Established in the Department of Housing and Urban Development is a program to assist nonprofit organizations in expanding specialized housing for relatives raising a child. To qualify for assistance, nonprofits must submit an application to the Secretary, ensuring coordination with a public housing agency. Assistance is need-based and provided on a competitive basis, with a limit on organizations selected each fiscal year. The program in the Department of Housing and Urban Development assists nonprofit organizations in expanding specialized housing for relatives raising a child. The Secretary may select up to 5 eligible organizations each fiscal year to receive assistance in the forms of new housing construction or rental voucher assistance for qualified relatives. The program assists nonprofit organizations in expanding specialized housing for relatives raising a child by providing project rental assistance and operational expenses for supportive services. Qualified relatives raising a child cannot be excluded from occupancy in such housing. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "child" refers to an individual under 18 years old not attending school or under 19 years old attending school. "Elderly person" is defined as someone who is 60 years or older. An "eligible nonprofit organization" provides specialized housing and social services for qualified relatives raising a child and is tax-exempt under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The term "qualified relative" refers to an individual who is an elderly person, not a parent of the child by blood or marriage, and a relative of the child by blood or marriage, including adopted children. The term "raising a child" refers to an individual who resides with and is the primary caregiver for a child, regardless of legal relationship, when the biological or adoptive parents are unable to fulfill that role. Specialized housing refers to affordable housing designed for low-income families with special physical needs, as defined by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Specialized housing for low-income families with special physical needs should accommodate supportive services tailored to the needs of elderly persons and children. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $20,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2018.
